capability.name: Quality Management System
capability.description: Comprehensive quality planning, inspection execution, non-conformance management, CAPA workflows, and quality analytics for continuous improvement

functions.name: Quality Inspection Planning & Execution
functions.description: Risk-based inspection planning with automated sampling plans, mobile inspection apps with AI-assisted defect identification, and real-time results capture

traditional.approach: Quality inspectors follow paper-based inspection plans with fixed sampling frequencies regardless of supplier performance or material criticality. Sampling plans are manually calculated using AQL tables and adjusted infrequently. Inspectors record results on paper forms or clipboards, which are later transcribed into quality management systems. Defect identification relies entirely on inspector expertise and judgment. Photos of defects are taken with cameras and uploaded separately. Inspection results are available only after data entry is complete, delaying response to quality issues.
limitations: Fixed inspection frequencies waste resources on low-risk suppliers while under-sampling high-risk ones
Manual sampling calculations are time-consuming and error-prone
Paper-based inspection creates data entry delays of 2-8 hours
Inconsistent defect identification depends on individual inspector expertise
Photos and notes are not linked directly to inspection records

agentic.approach: An orchestrator agent coordinates intelligent inspection planning and mobile-enabled execution. Risk assessment agents analyze supplier performance, material criticality, and defect history to dynamically adjust inspection frequencies and sampling intensities. Sampling agents automatically calculate optimal sample sizes using statistical methods and generate mobile-ready inspection checklists. Mobile execution agents provide inspectors with tablet/smartphone apps featuring guided workflows, AI-assisted defect identification using computer vision, and integrated photo capture. Real-time data agents immediately upload results to QMS, triggering automated containment actions for failures and updating supplier scorecards.

functions.name: Non-Conformance Management (NCR)
functions.description: Automated defect logging, root cause analysis workflows, containment action tracking, and quality issue resolution management

traditional.approach: Non-conformances are documented manually on paper NCR forms or basic electronic forms, describing the defect, quantity affected, and immediate containment actions. NCRs are routed through email for review by quality engineers and managers. Root cause analysis is performed manually through 5-Why or Fishbone exercises during meetings with stakeholders. Containment actions are tracked in spreadsheets with manual follow-up on completion status. Disposition decisions (scrap, rework, use-as-is) require multiple approvals via email. NCR closure requires manual verification that corrective actions are complete.
limitations: Manual NCR creation and routing delays response by 1-2 days
Root cause analysis is inconsistent and often superficial
Containment action tracking relies on manual follow-up
NCR status visibility is limited, frustrating stakeholders
Difficult to identify recurring issues across multiple NCRs

agentic.approach: An orchestrator agent coordinates end-to-end NCR management from defect detection through closure. NCR creation agents auto-populate defect details from inspection results, production reports, or customer complaints with integrated photos and measurements. Root cause agents guide structured RCA workflows (5-Why, Fishbone, Fault Tree) with AI-suggested potential causes based on similar historical issues. Containment agents automatically assign and track containment actions (sort, quarantine, supplier notification) with deadline monitoring and escalation. Disposition agents route materials to appropriate decision-makers based on rules and provide impact analysis. Analytics agents identify recurring defect patterns across suppliers, parts, and processes to prioritize systemic improvements.

functions.name: Corrective & Preventive Actions (CAPA)
functions.description: Automated CAPA workflow management, effectiveness verification through data analysis, and trend-based preventive action identification

traditional.approach: CAPA requests are manually created in response to quality failures, audits, or regulatory requirements. Action plans are documented in spreadsheets or basic workflow systems with assigned owners and due dates. Progress tracking relies on manual status updates during periodic review meetings. Effectiveness verification is subjective, based on qualitative assessments rather than data analysis. Preventive actions are reactive, initiated only after problems occur. CAPA completion rates are low (50-60%) due to competing priorities and lack of accountability. Regulatory compliance requires manual compilation of CAPA records for audits.
limitations: Manual CAPA creation and tracking leads to low completion rates (50-60%)
Effectiveness verification is subjective without data-driven validation
Preventive actions are reactive rather than proactive and predictive
Limited visibility into CAPA status creates accountability gaps
Difficult to link CAPA outcomes to quality performance improvements

agentic.approach: An orchestrator agent coordinates systematic CAPA management with predictive analytics. CAPA initiation agents automatically generate requests from NCRs, audit findings, or quality trend analysis with pre-populated background data. Action planning agents guide structured root cause analysis and action development, suggesting proven solutions from historical CAPA database. Workflow agents manage action assignments, deadline tracking, automated reminders, and escalation of overdue items. Effectiveness agents verify CAPA success through before/after data analysis of quality metrics (defect rates, customer complaints). Preventive analytics agents identify emerging quality trends and proactively suggest preventive actions before failures occur.

functions.name: Quality Audit Management
functions.description: Automated audit scheduling, digital execution with mobile apps, finding tracking with corrective actions, and audit program analytics

traditional.approach: Quality audits are scheduled manually based on annual calendars, with limited risk-based prioritization. Audit checklists are printed on paper, and auditors manually record findings during site visits. Audit reports are typed in Word or PowerPoint after the audit, causing delays of 1-2 weeks. Findings are tracked in Excel spreadsheets with manual follow-up on corrective actions. Audit effectiveness is assessed subjectively based on auditor experience. No systematic analysis of audit trends or recurring findings across facilities or suppliers.
limitations: Calendar-based scheduling misses emerging risks between scheduled audits
Paper-based execution delays audit reports by 1-2 weeks
Manual finding tracking has low closure rates (60-70%)
Limited visibility into audit status frustrates audited parties
No systematic identification of recurring findings across locations

agentic.approach: An orchestrator agent coordinates comprehensive audit program management. Scheduling agents use risk-based algorithms to prioritize audits based on performance trends, incident history, and regulatory requirements. Mobile execution agents provide auditors with tablet/smartphone apps featuring digital checklists, photo/video capture, and real-time finding documentation. Report generation agents automatically compile findings into standardized reports with supporting evidence immediately after audits. Finding management agents track corrective actions with automated reminders, escalation, and effectiveness verification. Analytics agents identify recurring findings across locations and generate insights for systemic improvements.

functions.name: Quality Analytics & Trending
functions.description: Real-time quality dashboards, defect pattern recognition using machine learning, predictive quality alerts, and Pareto analysis for improvement prioritization

traditional.approach: Quality metrics are manually compiled from inspection results, NCRs, and production reports into monthly Excel dashboards or PowerPoint presentations. Statistical analysis is performed manually using spreadsheets for basic control charts and Pareto diagrams. Trends are identified through visual inspection of historical charts, often missing subtle patterns. Quality reviews happen monthly or quarterly, providing lagging indicators that prevent timely intervention. Defect pattern analysis is ad-hoc and limited to obvious recurring issues. No predictive capability to anticipate quality degradation before defects occur.
limitations: Monthly reporting lag prevents timely quality intervention
Manual data compilation is time-consuming (20-30 hours/month)
Limited statistical analysis misses subtle quality trends
Reactive identification of issues after quality has degraded
Difficult to prioritize improvement efforts across multiple issues

agentic.approach: An orchestrator agent coordinates comprehensive quality analytics with real-time monitoring and predictive capabilities. Data collection agents continuously aggregate quality data from inspection systems, NCRs, production reports, and customer complaints. Analytics agents calculate real-time quality metrics (PPM, DPMO, FPY, Cpk) with statistical process control and automated out-of-control detection. Pattern recognition agents use machine learning to identify subtle defect correlations, supplier-specific trends, and seasonal variations. Predictive agents forecast quality degradation 2-4 weeks in advance based on leading indicators. Visualization agents generate dynamic dashboards with drill-down capability and Pareto analysis to prioritize improvement initiatives.

functions.name: Supplier Quality Management
functions.description: Supplier quality audits, certification tracking, quality agreement management, and collaborative quality improvement programs

traditional.approach: Supplier quality audits are scheduled manually based on new supplier qualification or periodic re-certification. Audit teams travel to supplier facilities with paper checklists and manually document observations. Audit reports are compiled after site visits and shared via email. Supplier certifications (ISO 9001, food safety) are tracked in spreadsheets with manual renewal monitoring. Quality agreements are static documents stored in shared drives, rarely reviewed or updated. Supplier quality improvement is ad-hoc, typically reactive to quality failures rather than proactive and collaborative.
limitations: Manual audit scheduling misses high-risk suppliers between periodic cycles
Paper-based audits delay reports and corrective action tracking
Certification expiration monitoring relies on manual calendar checks
Quality agreements become outdated without systematic review
Limited collaboration on quality improvement with supplier partners

agentic.approach: An orchestrator agent coordinates comprehensive supplier quality management. Risk assessment agents prioritize supplier audits based on performance trends, commodity criticality, and certification status. Audit management agents coordinate scheduling, provide mobile digital checklists, and generate automated reports with finding tracking. Certification agents monitor expiration dates, automatically request renewal documentation, and alert buyers to certification gaps. Quality agreement agents manage contract lifecycle including periodic reviews, performance-based updates, and change notifications. Collaboration agents facilitate joint quality improvement projects with suppliers, tracking initiatives and measuring outcomes.

functions.name: Quality Documentation & Records
functions.description: Electronic document control, automated version management, digital signatures, audit trails, and regulatory record retention

traditional.approach: Quality documents (procedures, work instructions, specifications) are stored in shared network drives or document management systems with manual version control. Document changes require physical signatures or email approvals before release. Revision tracking is maintained in spreadsheets or within document headers. Training records documenting employee review of procedures are collected on paper and filed manually. Audit trails for regulatory compliance are reconstructed manually when needed. Document retrieval for audits or investigations is time-consuming, requiring searches across multiple locations and file systems.
limitations: Manual version control leads to confusion about current vs. obsolete documents
Paper signatures delay document approval and release by days or weeks
Training records are incomplete with no verification of understanding
Difficult to prove document access and acknowledgment for regulatory compliance
Audit preparation requires manual compilation of records from multiple sources

agentic.approach: An orchestrator agent coordinates comprehensive quality document lifecycle management. Document control agents manage creation, review, approval workflow with electronic signatures, version control, and automated obsolete document removal. Access control agents enforce role-based permissions, track document views/downloads, and capture acknowledgment. Training agents automatically assign required reading to employees when procedures change, track completion, and verify understanding through quizzes. Audit trail agents maintain complete revision history, approval chains, and access logs with timestamps for regulatory compliance. Search agents enable rapid retrieval of current and historical documents with advanced filtering and content search.
